column3: My husband and I had a 12 hours layover before we head to our destination. We decided to take the Seoul Day City Tour ala our own way.We actually wanted to take the free tour provided by the Korean Government at the airport. The packages they offer are actually very good. However, they have a tight schedule that we must follow (for instance, leave exactly at 8 am and return to Incheon Airport at 1 pm). We asked whether we could leave the tour in the middle of the schedule and roam on our own but they told us it was not allowed to. So in the end we decided to do it on our own.We are happy to say that doing the tour on your own is very easy. The information table at Incheon Airport is very helpful. We were told to buy a tourist day pass which cost around 10 dollars. With this pass, you can get on most buses and trains from and to the airport and also around Seoul.The trains in Seoul are also easy to navigate. So you do not have to worry about getting lost. One important note though, exits can get a bit confusing because one train station can have up to 14 exits. So make sure you know exactly where you want to go.No need to worry about getting lost. First of all, wifi is everywhere and its free. So if you can easily use GPS wherever. Secondly, the Seoul people are very very helpful. Even if they cannot speak English (like the elderly) they will try their hardest to help you. One of our experiences was an old lady at the information centre helped us to call our friend with her own phone when all we asked was where is the nearest public phone. That was very sweet of her.While the places to visit, I recommend going to the Dream Design Play Building at Myeongdong, the King Seojeon statue and Gyeongbuk Palace at Gwanghamun Square, some shopping at Insadong, and try interesting cafes in Hongdae. If you still manage to catch the summer, make sure to try some Patbingsu! It is to die for!!!

3 of us did the Korea East Tour with WCP Adventure Camping in July 2013. It was a good way to experience a bit more of Korea & were glad we did it. Some of the places we visited would have been hard to get to without a car but this way we had someone to explain & organise it for us. It was good value, as well as great to be outdoors & see more than just city tourist spots. Sitting round the BBQ at night, near the beach, was particularly lovely as was climbing up Mount Seoraksan. Andy our guide was very conscientious re: our wellbeing & most helpful before & at the end of our trip & he helped us get the bus to our next destination. The camping kit and transport is new & very good. However, it is camping, so be prepared to rough it a bit, particularly with washing facilities. The places we stayed were mainly car parks in scenic locations rather than specific camping sites.We had just done a templestay (sleeping in dormitories on the floor) and had been staying in a traditional style B&B so the camping was fine for us. It is a new small company so the trips had not been running long and not everything went as smoothly as Andy would have liked - but for us that was part of the charm - & the adventure!

Visiting Korea ? If not go there the country is great and the places incredible. Biggest Christian churches in the world ( yes ). The palace is great too or even the airport inside the departure area is amazing with lots to do.

Seoul is as modern a city as they come, and at first glance can be compared to most other modern big cities. Still, underlying all that and all the Westernization, Seoul is still wholly Korean with historical touches found all over. With temples and markets interspersed with luxury hotels and department stores, everything you may be looking for can be found here.

After living in Seoul for over a year, I've been fortunate enough to experience so many wonderful events and attractions that make this city one of the best and most underrated in the world. First of all, its extremely safe. Crime is very very low in this country. Even in the middle of the night in a dark alley, its 100% safe. I know its hard to believe, but its true. Its the safest city in the world, in my opinion. Seoul is full of great attractions for families. There are tons of museums as well as Lotte World and Everland amusement parks. Throughout the year, there are various festivals and parades for all sort of occasions and holidays. The locals are kind, helpful to foreigners, and many of them can speak some English. The downtown areas are clean and expansive. There are various restaurants everywhere you go where you can try different kinds of traditional Korean foods at all price ranges. Also there are palaces scattered throughout the city that offer a look into the culture of Korean kingdoms of years past. There is so much to see and do here. Come over and see for yourself!!

I have been in Seoul couple of times, such a great city, but really hard as not many people understand English. Shopping is great and shops are open till late, shops are everywhere underground, on the streets, in a big massive buildings. Sometimes you can bargain with shop owners, but not everywhere. Was surprised as found quite a few shops, where you were not allowed to try clothes on.

Just got back from a 4days tour of Seoul,Korea. Seoul is definitely big..i would recommend more than 4 days stay. Try the seoul city tour hop-on-hop-off...its informative, cheaper and cover all interesting areas in Seoul. I particularly like the Seoul Museum, it consists of past and present artifacts about Seoul.They have a restaurant with reasonable prices beside the Family Mart(near entrance to the Museum). Its cheaper than most Korean restaurants we've been to.There's also a lovely view of the N Seoul Tower near the entrance of the Musuem. Don't forget to drop also to N Seoul Tower for a good view of Seoul. Everland is also a must try compared to Lotte World. Try the Safari World, my kids love it.Drop by during weekdays, weekends are very full. We waited 90minutes for the Safari World alone.TIP: You can bring water your own water and sandwiches inside the Everland.

When people think about populous cities, there are several cities which are coming to their mind: London, New York, Tokyo, Mexico City. But Seoul is in most of the cases not included. Seoul tends to be overlooked when it comes to great cities. This fact is a shame, because Seoul has so much to offer and so many things can be explored and discovered. Over ten million people are living in Seoul, twenty-five per cent of Korea’s population live in Seoul city and further 47 per cent live in Greater Seoul. As you can see, the city is the “soul” of South-Korea. The first impressions of Seoul I got were how huge the city is and how clean (even the subways) it is. Also, from the first moment I felt very safe in this big city and indeed Seoul is a relatively crime-free city.Seoul is divided into 25 major districts. The North Korean boarder lies around 50 km to the north. Most of the residents living in Seoul are Korean, with some small Japanese and Chinese minorities. International residents represent about 2% of the total population. Buddhism and Christianity are the two major religious in Seoul. In 1988 the city hosted the Summer Olympics and in 2002 the FIFA World Cup. It is the fifth most expensive cities in the world and the second most expensive city in Asia. The Han River bisects the city.How much is the daily life in Seoul? Public transport, basic meals, admission prices and accommodation are rather cheap, although famous restaurants and luxury hotels are expensive. Examples: 2km taxi ride: ₩1900, Cinema ticket: ₩7000, Litre bottle of water: ₩1000, Palace entry ticket: Free to ₩3000, Top-class dinner: ₩50,000. And if you like to travel within Korea, then I can give you an advice – you can save a lot of money if you book the famous Korean love motels. I have never seen so many motels in my life, but it is convenient. You get everything you need, it is clean and per night you pay around ₩30,000 for one room. Tipping is not necessary in Seoul. This is not common in Korea and people will insist on giving you change. You can use your credit card in nearly every shop, hotel and restaurant. Otherwise you can use the Global ATMs. They can be found outside banks, near subway stations, airports and department stores, as well as convenient stores. If you need a newspaper, Korea has three locally published English-language newspapers: the Korea Times and Korea Herald and not to forget the International Herald Tribune. Beside these three English-language newspapers, nearly every other magazine and newspaper is in Korean.Almost everything I experienced in Korea was different. The customs, the food and the writing-system are unlike anything in Western countries. For example parts of the street scenes are: “bali bali” (hurry, hurry), pushy people and scooter drivers on the sidewalk who absolutely don’t care if you move out of the way or not. And be prepared when it comes to communication. Few people speak English, but there is always a way to communicate. So, don’t worry! It is a part of the experience. Many restaurants in Seoul also have an English menu, but there are also many restaurants (especially on the countryside) with no English menu, so you have to order your food by picture.

people are friendly. food choices are awesome at reasonable prices. many places to visit. public transportation is so amazing. several hundreds of subway stations in and around Seoul. Bus system is awesome as well!

column2: “My short stay in Seoul, South Korea”
column3: I was in Seoul for 4 days and 3 nights. Coming back from a business trip in China. It was supposed to be a relaxed short stay. But what I got out was way more than it.Seoul was a lot like Shanghai, China(maybe it's the other way around). The street scene, the city, the store, the subway. It's like a modern asian city. The place is filled with coffee shop, brand name like Starbucks or Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf is everywhere, the density of those shops are so high, that you can see the whole street is filled with coffee shops.I heard lots of tourists love shopping in Seoul. I guess I really don't see much desire of shopping there. I can get way cheaper and better quality stuff anywhere in a mall in US. I don't see the appeal of that anywhere in Seoul.Food in Seoul is good, it's normal compare to other asian countries. BBQ is most made with pork. I need drink more next time to see whether it is that good.Overall experience is good. Just wish to have a bit longer

column2: “A Fabulous City to Visit - Wonderful People and Sites”
column3: Seoul is a huge city of 22 million within the regional area, yet it is clean, safe, and has excellent transportation. The historic sites and cultural attractions are incredible,10 UNESCO properties within a short distance - more than some countries have all together. Entrance fees are $1 or $2 or free for some of the largest, most incredible museums and cultural attractions in the world. If you are a vegetarian you will love it here - they eat lots of vegetables, rice and meat is always optional - the food is exquisite, fresh and it is fun to eat with metal chopsticks; much tricker than plastic or bamboo. At night the city comes to life with music lights, and you feel the dynamic of a major city like Paris, Bejing, New York or Frankfurt. There are very few homeless, the streets are clean and safe, and you can walk the various shopping districts, night and day in comfort. The shopping is amazing, they have stores and shopping districts that are larger than some North America cities! And if you want a cultural shopping experience - go to Isadong; if you want fashion, go to Meoyondong. And there are many markets where you can barter - but watch out, they know if you are a tourist - so negotiate, you always can. The airport is efficient, transportation efficient, but watch the taxi prices to and from the airport. They charge you for the driver, and the tolls, but our driver never told us. To take the limo bus was $30, the taxi drive who was to take us to the limo bus told us he could drive us to the airport for $50 - so we said yes. When we arrived, he charged us $70 as he paid a $7.50 toll bridge in, and presumably then again out, plus a $5 extra fee! So while the ride was comfortable, this was the only dishonest experience we had. For english speaking people, there are folks who can help you, but be prepared to be immersed in a language and culture where Koreans, Japanese and Chinese represent the majority of tourists - it is simply wonderful if you like to mix with foreign environments and don't mind a few adventures with limited language! I will definately return and recommend to my friends.

Date: 2010/01/29After planning for so long, finally I arrived Seoul.Thank GOD, I made it!!!To be here in Seoul, and have chance to enjoy a greaaaaaaaaat concert in 잠실종합운동장( Jamsil Olympic Stadium) with BigBang and VIP.I really enjoyed the concert, BigBang really had a great show!I enjoyed the video they took, they are so cute!!!!Especially GD, when he woke up, his hair style is so cute. :)Though he put on his hat right away...........XDDDI also love Taeyang's solo performance!!!I loooooooooove his song "WHERE U AT" and "WEDDING DRESS".In the concert TOP also revealed his new song "Turn it up",although I couldn't realize the meaning of the lyrics,I was impressed by the music video. TOP is so cool!!!I love BigBang's songs!Their songs were so cool.I wish I could go to their concert again!Again and again!!（←2PM？ hah）

My wife and I had our holiday in Seoul in beginning of June. I must say that it is the one of the best trips we ever had. Before we leave for Seoul, we are expecting that everything is Seoul is expensive due to the fact that she is one of the most expensive cities to live in in the world. But to our surprise, we found it the opposite. Food in restaurants is very reasonably priced, I can say that it is cheaper than the same meal in my home city, Jakarta Indonesia. We tried some of the restaurants that is recommended by tripadvisor and it is not to be disappointed. We did a lot of shopping but not once, we stepped into a department store. We went to Insadong, Namdaemun Market and Myeongdong to shop and found a lot of bargains. The people of Seoul are very friendly towards the tourist and there are many tourist information centre to help us. They will walk to you if you look confused and help you in everyway. Great food, Great Shopping, Friendly People, had a nice hotel to stay.....what more can I ask?

column2: “Overlooked city ... although it has sooo much to offer!”
column3: Being the first time in Seoul, South Korea, I was amazed! I didn’t expect the city to be that vibrant, lively, and upcoming/modern. Luckily I was there before the rainy/wet/hot season; so May/early June seems to be good. Culture-wise Seoul offers sooo much (especially World Heritage sites, but also art galleries, very authentic food places, etc.). I definitely will come back, as this – in my opinion – is one of the most underestimated travel destinations in Asia. As a downside, though, I think the size and the “outspreadness” of the city is something to bare in mind, when planning a trip.

The trip to Seoul was an experience. November was cold ( -14C ) and I could feel my feet goin numb even while walking on the street. We had to walk into a store every 5 mins to keep warm. the food was great..an experience in itslef with the grill and the iceberg lettuces that go with every meal. Its a great place for shopping too... A TIP : go thru a local Travel agent for a trip to the DMZ ...going thru the hotel was extremely expensive...in the DMZ , go thru the tunnels only if you are fit and fine...it can get very tiring...overall the place was clean, the food was great and the people were very friendly..Nice place.

Sally and I arrived in Seoul with our little travel map that we got from our hotel. The Rainbow Hotel was very clean & inexpensive, but from a western standard, needs some improvements. 8000 won ($8.00 AUD) via a very clean bus to our destination from the international airport. Language was the main issue as there was very little signage in English. This aside, the locals were very helpful in advising us where to get off and also one girl directed us to our hotel. Great service. We walked around the city for the next day, visited the Imperial War Museum. Huge place and well worth the admission fee. We had a Korean guide the next day. He was brilliant! English speaking and very knowledgable.Well done Bumsoo Kim! Food is brilliant! Cheap, filling and lots of it. The last day we had to try a Korean BBQ. We found one in the Yongsungoo District just around the corner from the hotel. Once again, we were not disappointed! The food was excellent, the table was packed with condiments and replenished as used. For $8 AUD, it was well worth it. $4 for a 500ml beer or $2 from the 7-11. We will definately go again!!

A friend and I decided to go to South Korea on a whim. See, most people our age would choose to go to places like Hong Kong or Singapore for shopping. But since we're not big shoppers, and Manila's currently being invaded by the Korean fever, we wanted to know what the fuss was all about. We didn't want to invest too much so we decided to get a budget hotel, Garbato Hotel at Hawolgok-dong, Sungbuk-Ku.Day 1: Traffic was bad going to the city from Incheon so we got there at about 11-ish and at that point in time, we were dying to lie down on a bed. The previous review was right. It was about a 5-min walk from the Wolgok subway station and a stone throw away from the SK gas station. The hotel looks cozy but unfortunately, we never got to see the insides of the rooms. While checking in, the owner, Mr. Hiroshi Matsunami, pulled us aside and told us that they overbooked. I was tired and confused, I couldn't think straight. Fortunately, Mr. Hiroshi-san was a kind businessman and have made prior arrangements for us to transfer to another hotel, with all expenses paid! I couldn't believe our luck! How lucky were we to encounter such honest, kind man at a time like this! He was truly a good man and I thank God that there are people like him left in the world. If only for that experience, I would go back to the Garbato Hotel and write a good review even without experiencing their in-house service. When we finally got to our new hotel, Hotel Noblesse at Yeoksam, we were hungry as hell so we walked to the nearest food establishment that's still open. We paid about 25,000 Won for a fried chicken dish which is expensive by Philippine standards since there was nothing special about the chicken. But we haven't eaten dinner at 2am so I could eat anything at this point. Finally at about 3am, we were able to catch some sleep before out big day.Day 2: On our first full day, we decided to get our cultural sightseeing and shopping over with and headed towards the Geongbokgung Palace. The sites were fantastic! Especially when they were changing guards around noontime. The costumes, the handpainted ceilings, the gardens were a feast for the eyes. I felt like I was watching one of those Korean-novelas on TV live. The National Folk Museum of Korea is a must see as well. The locals were friendly and although they have difficulties with English, they try hard to make the tourists happy. Our day was starting right. At around 2pm, we decided to get some shopping therapy and headed towards Insa-dong. From the Jong 3 (sam)-ga subway station, we walked straight into a local Korean restaurant for lunch. It was a traditional restaurant so we sat on the floor and ordered some Kimchi Pork Stew and rice. It was served with the traditional Kimchi, pickled Zucchini and Fried Seaweed Stems with a sour-like sauce that I can't identify. Our meal was fantastic and very affordable at 7,000 won in total! After that, we walked to Insa-dong and it was a sight to see. The street was filled with tourists and locals alike and was lined with street vendors selling anything between little knick-knacks, hats, street snacks, cherries, candies, etc. It was definitely an experience. At the middle of the street was a park where free drinks from tea, hot chocolate, coffee and popcorn where passed around. I love Seoul! After hours of shopping, we headed towards the Gangbuk Jeongdong Nanta Theater for the 8pm show. Although tickets should be reserved at least a day before, we were lucky that a couple of seats were still available. The theater was small, probably about 200-seater but was jampacked with tourists. The show is a must see in Korea! I was laughing the whole 1-1/2 hrs so I will definitely go back if given the chance. The actors were multi-skilled performing like standup comedians, doing stunts, magic, interacting with the audience without talking so even non-Korean or English speaking audiences would be able to appreciate it. After the show, we went to a small local restaurant across the theater and grabbed a quick bibimbap and ramyeon dinner. Nothing spectacular but it was filling for the price so no complaints there.Day 3: Our third day was allotted for some amusement park fun at the Everland theme park. We had some problems looking for the bus stop going to the park so for first timers, it's actually the bus stop in front of the Who.A.U flagship store at Gangnam. It was about an hour ride, including traffic. We didn't get to enjoy most of the signature rides like the T-express or any of the roller coaster rides because of the rain but the rose garden and the four seasons flower garden were a sight to see. On our way back to the city, we stopped by one of the inner walk local restaurants to get some Jjigae stew that's cooked on a stove top on the dining table. Because we were at downtown Seoul, the price was fit for downtown dining but it was a different experience cooking and eating at the same time so it was good value for the price. Finally at 2am, we got home and rested our throbbing feet in preparation for last day.Day 4: Our last day in Korea was a Sunday. It was still raining and we only have half a day to do some last minute siteseeing and shopping so we thought we'd limit our trip to the Dongdaemum market which supposedly was open 24hrs a day. This was not entirely true since when we got there, we didnt see any open establishment so we decided to just head back to Insa-dong for a quick lunch at our now favorite little restaurant and some last minute souvenir shopping. We got some walnut cakes which are yummy and tasty specially when hot and picked up some extra souvenirs to be given to friends at home. After struggling to haggle with the non-English speaking front desk officer at the hotel, we checked out at 2:30pm and headed to the Airport Express bus terminal at Gangnam. After an hour we got to the Incheon International Airport. The airport is huge and as impressive as the Hong Kong International airport (sorry Changi, I wasn't that impressed with you) housing some well known international brands and local souvenir shops. You need to catch a short train ride to the 100+ gates so make sure you allot at least 30mins going to those gates.I was sad to leave because in 3-1/2 days, I got to love Seoul. If given the chance, I would definitely go back!

seoul is the cleanest city we have ever visited and we have traveled through out the world. the people were helpful even when they spoke no english they would find others to help us get around the city.i recommend those that think all asian cities are all alike to take a visit and see this fantastic city.

Seoul-Free And Easywe had an excellent one day tour of seoul organised by US TOUR-email master@ustravel.kr, thier tour guide B H YOO email [--] was a real gentleman and so informative-the korean culture, history, food, politics and no pressure shopping. We had a excellent introduction to seoul and korean way of life and sightseeing. We were hesitant at first, the ongoing war talk from the north korea, after this one day visit we felt as safe as anywhere in the world. We visited the king's palace, the korean folk village, the korean folk museum, passby the presidential palace, ate a typical korean lunchbimbibak I think. It's really healthy.The city is spotless clean, very polite people, even changed money for us when we are stuck with big notes in the local bus ride. Great bargains at the namdaemun and dongdaemun markets.And the usual high end fashions and the big prices.The Ibis Hotel in Myeong Dong is in a fantastic location, close to everything and bend back wards to please us and the other customersYou will just love Seoul, like us.

If you like to shop -- don't miss visiting the MANY marketplaces of Seoul! You will NOT be disappointed. Surf the internet in advance of your trip and print out maps and location names for the places you want to visit in Hangul. These will come in handy when you are asking for directions or needing to provide a place name and location to taxi drivers. The only drawback is you'll want to return again and again!

I visited Seoul Korea and Hanyang University May 2009. While there, I used the subway system (which is spotless), went shopping, visited temples and palaces and watched a baseball game. The baseball game was the high-light of my trip. I cheered for the Doosan Bears against the Lotte Tigers. The Bears won!

When my wife and I first arrived in Seoul, a man came up to us at the airport and asked us if we needed a cab. Yes we replied. We asked him how much it would be to get to our hotel, The Ibis Ambassador Seoul which is by the Coex. All he said was that it was metered. It seemed like he didn't really understand English so we let it go and followed him to his cab which was parked in the lot. I thought it was a bit strange but went along with it anyways. I didn't know that the hotel was 70 km from the airport which is about 43.5 miles. I noticed the meter was up to 60,000 Korean won which is equivalent to around $52 US. And it seemed like we had a long way to go. After I complained about the price, the driver said that there were 2 types of cabs, a regular taxi and the black taxi. He was the black taxi. I found out later they charge almost double the regular taxi. The whole ride cost us 130,000 won ($113 US). I gave him a credit card to pay for it, he seemed to want cash, of course. But had to take my card since I didn't have enough cash. I felt a little better that he was bothered by that, but he still took my money and got the better of me. SO BEWARE OF THE BLACK TAXI. Later I found out that I could have taken a shuttle bus to my hotel which would have cost a lot less. 28,000 won ($25 US) Besides this, I had a great time in Seoul.

Such a great city.-Very safe city with low crime rate.-Locals are very friendly and polite.-Clean and well organised.-Efficient, secure, clean and cheap public transit.-Plentiful clean public washrooms.-Attractions and food are inexpensive.-Incheon airport is the best in the world.-A shoppers paradise.

The graciousness and hospitality of the Korean people are unmatched by any in our travels. Seoul is a beautiful city filled with rich history, lovely architecture and charming neighborhoods. The restaurants are delightful... be sure to sample the kimchi and the cold noodle soup. Watch out for the hot peppers in the bibimbap!

column2: “Seoul - the friendly city where ancient and modern exist side by side.”
column3: In April 2009, I spent 10 days in and around Seoul, Korea. April is the ideal month for it. The cherry blossoms, the forsythias, and the azaleas are in full bloom. It is a relatively dry month and the temperature is climbing from light jacket weather to shirt sleeves. You miss the uncomfortable heat of summer and the highway-clogging traffic of the popular fall vacation period.I stayed at the Stay 7 Hotel , Seoul National University Station on the south side of the Han River. It was modestly priced, an excellent value. My room was clean, and the staff was very helpful. The day before I returned home they even took care of shipping the gifts I had purchased. I turned the items over to the man at the counter. He weighed them, he told me the cost, I paid him and didn't see the gifts again until about three weeks later when I picked them up at my local post office. All of the items were there, and they were in the same perfect condition as they were when I last saw them in Korea.One of my first stops was the Hanock Folk Village on the side of Namsan (South Mountain). Well kept upper class homes from the Chosen Dynasty had been moved there to create the attracttion.At the very top of the mountain is the ultra-modern Seoul Tower , one of the highest towers in Asia. It is roughly the equivalent of the "Space Needle" in Seattle U.S.A. Dinner there was by reservation, and I had planned ahead. Following the recommendation of the waiter, I ordered the kalbi (beef rib strips). The meal was fresh, hot, and tasty.Another of my stops in Seoul was Changdok palace, one of three major palaces in Seoul. Having visited the other two in earlier visits to Seoul, I was looking forward to visiting this one. Of the three, I found that Changdok is undeniably the most beautiful. All three palaces are nestled in downtown Seoul. The tall commercial buildings of Seoul loom a bit incongruously above the palace walls.The place where I had the most fun was the national museum. Many of the ancient treasures of Korea are housed in this huge modern building in the Yong San section. There were many school trips that had the museum as their destination that day. The children were friendly and all wanted to practice the extent of their English with me. I felt like a rock star.Seoul has a wonderful subway system. It is safe, extremely clean, and low priced. It extends perhaps thrity miles both north and south of the city center. I am told that it now goes all the way to the airport in Inchon in the west. Several times, I had the pleasure of talking with the locals between stations.Other great stops during my visit included shopping on Insadong Street and in Namdaemun market. Close by Namdaemun is Shin-Si-Gae, a very upscale department store. If you are looking for names like Gucci, Ralph Lauren, and Channel, this is where you want to go.The old South Gate of Seoul (Namdaemun) had burned down more than a year earlier. It was about 613 years old, and it was Korea's greatest treasure. Behind a covering, workmen were busily reconstructing it. In another year or two, it should be completed.My visit to Seoul was excellent, and I can't wait to return again.

column2: “My favorite things to do in South Korea”
column3: Must-see and do when in South Korea1. USO tour to DMZ (de-militarization zone between North and South Korea).2. Visit a jjimjilbang (a korean spa...be sure to get a full body scrub) and Visit Dr. Fish Cafe to have fish eat the dead skin off your feet and legs (after you have coffee).3. Visit Souwan, a walled city south of Seoul4. Go to a noreabang...karaoke Korean style in privates rooms for your group.5. Enjoy galbi (Korean barbecue).

column2: “My list of things to do in Seoul”
column3: There's nothing truly spectacular in Seoul. It's no Tokyo in terms of things modern and no Beijing in terms of things ancient. Yet I think the city borders on sheer awesomeness. Here's what I'd do if I had five days in Seoul.1. Walk around Insadong-gil (gil is the word for street). Now you might say what kind of a tip is this as Insadong is the prime tourist area of Seoul. The thing is, the city isn't touristy at all, so the few Westerners hanging out there don't make you feel like you've walked into a another tourist trap. Instead I was caught up in a street theater performance in which I assume, I was made fun of to the point, that five hours later, when I passed the place again walking back to my guesthouse, there were people there pointing at me and laughing. It was brilliant. I also spend some time watching a tae-kwon-do performance and a bad Korean band. And it's all free, folks.2. Seoul's palaces are hardly a match for their Japanese counterparts (Japanese raids have made sure of that) but I really liked Changdeokgung. Even though in order to see it you have to join a tour, which is both rushed and poorly guided, it's a nice place to visit. Biwon, the secret garden, is rather pretty.3. Take a hike! Seoul is probably the only big city in the world which boasts hiking trails within the city's central area. The Inwangsan peak offers a nice walk up along trails which feature some pretty random shamanistic points of worship (they looked like big rocks to me).Not only is there hiking within central Seoul, the Bukhansan national park can be reached in about 30 minutes by subway.Both get really busy on the weekends. I didn't mind the crowds as I thought it was quite funny to pose for the Korean hikers to whom I seemed to be a bigger attraction than the sweeping views I failed to photograph.4. Party hard! Seoul has a two very different centers for nightlife. My favorite is the area around Hongik university, where the cool kids congragate. Beats me what I was doing there. It has a bit of an indie music scene and some bigger clubbing venues. (Subway: Hongik uni).A truely surreal party scene can be found in Itaewon, the expat part of the city. Friday and Saturday nights are at their bizarrest at 1.45AM as the curfew for the good old boys from the nearby US military base is at 2AM. So till 1.45 you can just gape at the sheer madness of their partying and then within 15 minutes they are all gone. The military police patrols Itaewon on weekends just to make sure that the boys, many of whom have been stationed in Afganistan and Iraq before, make it to bed in time. I had a mad fun night in Itaewon, the highlight of which was shaking hands with a member of the US olympic basketball team in a bar on a strip aptly called Hooker Hill. Beats me what I was doing there. (Subway: Itaewon)5. Take both of the two USO tours to the de-militarized zone on the border of South and North Korea. Gape at the North Korean soldier looking at you through binoculars (not the one in the pic on the left), visit the little blue house were they hold peace talks and slouch in the North Korean infiltration tunnel. Take the tour in the beginning of your trip as it gives you a quite an intriguing perspective to the country.Further recommendations:6. Namsam hill and tower for views and lovers locks. (in the pic on the left)7. Han river for people spotting.8. Dongdaemum market for night time shopping.9. Dongbang Sauna for bathing (Subway: Hongik Uni)10. Seodaemum prison for some fake blood and torture exhibits.Pics and more lists at http://99countries.blogspot.com

We visited Seoul in October 2008 in order to see a bit of autumn colour. Although autumn wasn't yet in full swing when we arrived the trees were still quite colourful and beautiful.When I was researching for our trip I came across pictures of a fairly new attraction - Cheonggye Stream. I was not over interested as it was just a stream and its surroundings looked concretey and artificial, but to our surprise when we visited we really liked it..The stream was at one time badly polluted and covered over by an elevated roadway. As part of an attempt to beautify Seoul the stream was cleaned up and the roadway removed. Walkways were build along each side of the stream.When we arrived at the stream, we found a large proportion of Seoul's population had headed there, too. The walkways were lined with families, business men, groups of friends and young lovers out for a pleasant stroll or sitting down to a picnic lunch or simply taking a brief nap and enjoying the sunshine.Several bridges cross over the stream and at various points you can cross by leaping over paving stones. The locals were so excited by this prospect that we watched several people, mainly children, fall in and get rescued.Points of interest along the stream include manmade waterfalls, fountains, plastic flowers with giant eyeballs in their centre, a water powered gramophone repeatedly playing the same note over and over again and a display of brightly coloured stripy umbrellas suspended over one area of the stream.A pleasant spot to bathe your feet in the cool water and watch the world pass by.A second outing we enjoyed was a visit to Inwangsan Village located one stop past Gyongbok Palace on the underground.This village is famous for its shammanist temples with their brightly coloured wall paintings. At one point these temples were located on Mount Namsan but then they were banned during the Japanese occupation and secretly relocated to Inwangsan.The village is reached via a steep hill with a brightly coloured temple gateway. One of its temples is famous for its large bronze bell.We were fortunate enough to see a shamanist ceremony in one of the temples during our visit.Attracted by the music and chanting, we watched from a distance as the shaman repeatedly changed her brightly coloured robes and swirled around waving brightly coloured pieces of cloth. We didn't go too close as we did not want to be a nusiance and this turned out to be a wise move as part of the ceremony involved hurling handfuls of rice and eggs through the temple doors much to the delight of the local bird population which swooped down on them within seconds.This area also has several oddly shaped rocks and small rock carvings of Buddha. There is also a section of restored city wall winding up the mountains which looked interesting but on this occasion we did not have time to follow it. Well worth a visit.

After drinking half my coffee, I looked down while sipping and noticed a thick coffee ring around the inside of the mug, lower than the current level of my coffee. It came off when we wiped a finger through it. The staff, who seemed very stressed in general, apologized in an offhand fashion. I had previously returned my first cup of coffee after the creamer curdled in it. That mug had been dirty on the outside, but I had been going to use it anyway.Our breakfast of pancakes, eggs, bacon, sausage, hashbrowns and toast was below average and disappointing. I left the sausage on the plate... it appeared to have been lightly fried and the perhaps boiled, with white-ish fat left on the surface. It had little flavor. The coffee was somewhat watery, the fried eggs rubbery.The green indoor/outdoor carpet in the main room is worn almost black in the aisles. The carpet in the patio area is torn; a waiter almost tripped while serving some of our fellow diners.We found this place to be unsanitary, the food substandard, and the staff very harried. No matter how much you might be craving a Western breakfast, this is not the place to go.

One of the top commercial and finnancial cities in the world, Seoul has about a quater of all South Korea population. Metropolitan area has about 25 million and Seoul itself, over 10 million.Place of world companies as Samsung, LG and Hyundai has a high standard of living and a lot to be seen.There are the round trip buses with stops in all major atractions around downtown, where people can junp off and after visiting the spot, come back to take the bus again. This buses run from around 10 till after dark.A visit should begin with the 3 royal palaces ( Changdeokgung, National Folk Museum and Gyeongbokgung) although exist some others.Insadong district is lined with galleries, handcraft shops, theaters and traditional restaurants.Itaewon is the place for international community and has a good nightlife. English is a common language here.For shop windowers the right place can be Apgujeongdong, where live the richest koreans. Beautiful department stores and upscale restaurants are places for hunters of tv and korean movie stars.Bargains hunters should visit Namdaemun Market with its open air shops. Here one can find almost everything. From clothes to flowers, from korean art to imported goods.Han River crosses the cities and is point for relaxing and entertainment. Lots of restaurants, nice view of Seoul´s skyscrapers, boat trips, etc.Namsan Park has a small zoo and botanical garten but the best part is the cable car that leads to the top of the mountain from where we can see a 360 grades view of the city.Seul´s World Cup Stadium and Museum - modern and well equipped is sourrounded for several parks.All major attractions can be reached through underground for it covers virtually all the city and metropolitan area.For night views there are the Seoul Tower (Through Cable car), the 63 Building (tallest building in Seoul) and Bukak skyway.

I went to Seoul for a week to visit a special friend. The city is lively and the people are very nice especially to a tourist like me. There's a blend of modern and ancient culture. I've visited temples and palaces and they are all magnificent. The best way to see the whole view of the city is to go to the top of Seoul Tower in Mt. Namsan through a cable car. If you want to buy souvenirs, you visit Insa-dong. There are a lot of beautiful and interesting places to see. Transportation is inexpensive and my advice is take the subway-it's quick and cheap! Enjoy travelling!!!

I went to South Korea Last December 2007 winter.My sister and i went there for 2 weeks vacation in Korea. We joined the 5 day tour to adapt the country first before finding our Korean friends.Frankly speaking, my sister and i detest the group tour because we had a very irresponsible tour guide who cheat our money just because we are much more younger than the rest. First they did not mention anything about the extra tour guide joining us. This made us prepare another set of tips for them. Secondly, just because my sister and i go alone for holiday in such a young age, that tour guide discriminate us. Why? It's all because we went out alone exploring the streets outside. The tour ended at 7pm and we had nothing to do in the guesthouse. So my sister and i decided to roam around the streets, getting use to the city life. The next day, the tour guide wasn't happy with us and scolded us and just because we are going separate ways after the tour the following day, ( The rest of the group going back to Singapore ) the tour guide claim her tips first. We felt extremely cheated during the last day morning before we leave. The photographs that the tour guide took for us, they did not tell us anything and just wanted us to pay 60 000 (S$100) just for 12 photos without choosing! We were not use of the currency and also, they were pushing us while at the last minute when we had to leave.After realizing that we was cheated, we sent an angry email back to Singapore to complain about this incident and Singapore agency manage to contact us and refund us the money to us on the photos that we do not want to buy. Anyway, the 12 photos were extremely expensive. 12 photos for $100, this is way too expensive!This tour was very bad, the food that they served was totally different from what true Korean food was being served. During the 5 days tour, almost everyday we were eating steamboat and nothing else. Tour ended so early at 7pm and we have nowhere to go.After separating with the tour group, we finally had our freedom. We know that the tour need to follow schedule, that's why they are always rushing for time. However, imagine, going to a theme park for less than 3 hours. Going to unnecessary places like ginseng shop and jewelry shop for an hour, if they exclude this 2 tour out, we can able to spend more time in other stuffs like shopping and sight-seeing.The tour outside Seoul was pretty good with good accommodation and food but after we reached to Seoul, the tour was disastrous!When we joined our friends. We stayed in their house till we left for Singapore. We really enjoyed our stay in Seoul. It was totally different feelings from the tour and free and easy. I now know why people dislike going to Korea, because the tour did not show what's the true feeling of Korea!The street food was extremely delicious, wonderful shopping, able to tour around buildings and seeing the true side of Korea, the trip was good! It might be difficult to communicate with Koreans however, their English wasn't that bad after all. We can still able to speak simple English and that's good enough. The weather was cold and during the 2 weeks, there was snow and my sister and i was very excited over it. I love to eat krispy kreme donuts and the trends in there was cool.I love there especially with my Korean friends bringing us to places that sells delicious food that we, the foreigners will dream to try those delicious food like cheese rice cakes with noodles. And yes, i am addicted with their instant noodles. =)Definitely miss Korea and i hope to visit them again soon. But this time round, i want to go during spring! =D

My mother and I travel to Seoul about 6 day.We know alot of Korea history at War Memorial Museum.The view at Mountain Sorak is very wonderful.We learn alot of culture when we visit the MBC theme park which is the place that shooting the famous drama Daejanggeum (Jewel in The Palace).Their food is very deliciouse.I recommended alot of my friend travel to Korea.

column2: “South Korea, I'm sorry but is boring.”
column3: And it has not anything to do with people from there, they are very nice and if you want to know asian culture is a great place to stay for one week, and that's it. I lived at one hour from Seoul for year and a half, and went to that city several times, got enough of it super fast. BORING.

I lived in Seoul for 13 months, and it has its "up and downs". Traffic is horrible, and much of the city stinks, but it is an experience in its-self. Be sure to see the war museum and the Itaewon Market.

For my brothers wedding we travelled to Seoul in October 2006. A totally different experience as a) on the other side of the globe and b) compared to standard destinations we had been to a new experience in general.Upon our arrival and after 13 hours flight we had to struggle keeping up for the rest of the day as it was only 7AM !! On top of that it was very humid and warm. Not knowing any Korean language, we felt like completely lost (although the basics like thanks and hello got better during the stay)People are really friendly and look at you quite curious due to being European, whcih they don't see often.Seoul itself is a buzzing city, with 12 million inhabitants. The accommodation was different, too but funny. The food- I tried as much as possible, being curious and adapting to the country but I have to say sometimes I rather sticked to what I already knew foodwise from my sister-in-law and my brother. If you travel to Korea, don't expect Restaurants to have an English menu. You do have alternative restaurants, though and as said people are trying to help you in finding a good meal.The attractions were great. A combination of old and new. You have skyscrapers one side and old temples and palaces the other side.It was a very short trip though, hence we definately will go there again, to visit the coast region and its small islands around.More and more Europeans are making their way to Korea which is a good thing. It's a country worth seeing !!

I lived in Seoul, South Korea for approximately five years as an English teacher. Even though I was originally born there, I left the country as a child and returned as an adult, only to find that the place bore no resemblance to anything in my memories.The city is a bustling metropolis with major western businesses located in the downtown area and the ever so ubiquitous Star Bucks coffee shop on every block.Ever since the 1988 Olympics, the city took on a challenge to really westernize. For English speaking foreigners this is the mecca of all locations to teach, since the exchange rate is often more favorable to the westerners and the inexpensive living costs allow teachers to save more money than they would if he or she were to teach elsewhere in Asia, say Japan or China.The best part of the city is its user-friendly metro system that conveniently go everywhere - even to the outer satellite cities like Bundang or Suwon. The bus system is also easy to use, but you may have to get the help of a Korean-speaker, since the schedules are not in English.There are several must-see highlights, depending on how long you stay.1. Panmunjeom - a tour of the DMZ can be arranged through a local tourist office or through the USO. I've heard that the USO offers a better tour, since you can actually tour an area where Korean locals cannot.2. Namsan tower - smack dab in the middle of the park under the same moniker, the tower has been recently renovated and boasts a restaurant from where you can look far out into the city3. Insadong - this quaint neighborhood is the gallery to the ancient Korean culture, as well as up and coming art scene. A great place to pick up souvenirs and antiques.4. Great Wall of Korea in Suwon - not the exact name of the attraction, but like the wall in China, this wall was also built to deter attacking outsiders.5. Shopping - there are several great locations, but all for different reasons:-- Myeongdong and Dondaemun Shopping Area - if you're in the area for a longer period of time than a simple two-week vacation, this is the place to shop for clothing. Korea produces inexpensive, trendy clothes. You can also find some designer knock-offs here. Be ware - the majority of Korean population is slim, so any Americans above the size 10 for women will have a hard time finding anything that fits. The same goes for shoes - the largest size mass produced is 255 (equivalent to size 9 in American).-- Namdaemun market - this is an outdoor market for the thrifty and low-income locals. I believe most of the products come from China and are inexpensive, but you'll have to forgo the quality as well. But still an interesting place to take photos. If you've never been to an outdoor market, this place is a must. You'll see, smell, and hear something that you've never experienced.-- Ewha Women's University Area - as you may have guessed, this is the mecca of all college-aged women, from clothing to hair. You'll find some of the city's best fashion emerging from here. Plus the neighborhood is filled with various hair-salons that charge decent prices. It's usually best to go and get conditioning treatment or a perm, since the hair cuts are complementary in the package. A hair coloring/highlight can cost anywhere from US $35-80, depending on the place.-- Itaewon - where all foreigners converge, you'll find the most diverse types of restaurants here. This is also where you can find many foreign-owned bars where you can meet up with some of your compatriots. A local favorite is the Canada Bar. A word of caution: compared to other parts of the city, this place is on the more seedy side, so take care of your bags and belongings.On the flip side of the charm, Seoul is heavily polluted (air and water). Many foreigners (myself included) get very ill with the flu several times a year. So for an extended stay, make sure you pack your vitamins! They are expensive and hard to find in Korea.

You land at Incheon Airport to get to Seoul. The capital of Republic of Korea. The airport and its surrounding, budding city is located on reclaimed island and you can marvel at its vast expanse and the construction work going on everywhere. By April next year it will be linked to mainland by train also, but at present you have to restrict yourself to road link. As everywhere else, avoid taxicabs. They are far too expensive (50 US$ minimum) to go the downtown area. Two bus services (both excellent) shuttle between city and Incheon. In less than an hour you find yourself in the city, which is and should teeming with Koreans. Now you are on your own. English is out, Korean is in but unless you know Korean, you must be prepared to face lots of hardship. But don't lose heart. You are in the one of the most helpful and cheerful people, the residents of Seoul. Tourist attractions can be divided into the cultural/ heritage ones, the shopping districts, the cuisine and food and large 5 star hotel visits (unless you are staying in one, you can omit the last).First and foremost for cultural/heritage things are the sprawling palaces in Seoul and the large natural reserves and forests. Museums are many. From National museum to War memorial one, they are all very well kept and worth a visit. The Seoul city government has a specialized "palace tour" which takes you to almost every noticeable palace. The tours to DMZ (demilitarized zone) and the night tour are separate from the routine ones and are worth taken. Korean history had three dynasties. You can watch the remains of all three. The Seoul tower is built at Namsan Mountain, which also is the place where in 10th century the emperor ordered a wall to be built to keep the offending armies at bay. This wall was later broken during Japanese occupation, but since 1975-6 reconstruction work is being done. Tower has a cable car also and its one of the fascinating place to visit once you reach downtown Seoul. Next are the palaces, but here is a word of caution: Your English and Koreans' may not coincide well and resultant situation may not guide you properly and may cause exasperation and extreme displeasure, avoid that. Give the Koreans marks for their help and don't mind if they are not the followers of 'great English language' revolution. After all they were not taught spoken English in their hometowns and even schools for a long time. But their hearts are of Gold. You can always count on their smiles and once understood, you will marvel at the amount of time they spend to just help you out of any situation. Their language is hard to understand. The phrases in your cute guide books may never tell you the real pronunciation and don't get sad if your 'thank you’ (KHAMSA HAMIDA) doesn't get a prompt 'you are welcome' response. Chances are your pronunciation was never understood. Be patient in these situations as there will be more and more of them if you don't have a proper guide or local guy to be with you as the interpreter.Bars and pubs are not Korean. They have 'hofs' instead. Almost everywhere in Seoul you will find a large number of coffeehouses where you can get the best coffee from any country and in any form you like. Specialized coffeehouses and bakers have higher price tags though, but they deserve one visit to get to know the taste of Korean coffee craze. People who try to find 'night life' will not really love Korea. The famous international brand selling road and area "Itaewan" does boast of a few clubs but you almost invariably never find the host of brothels and striptease joints in Seoul. Koreans have magnificently maintained their culture and traditions through times and have proved to the world that hitech progress has nothing to do with getting out of your clothes. This aspect of Korean life is so apparent and no matter what others says about lack of 'sex aesthetics' about it, they are not going to change. Telephone booths characteristically don't have those huge 'directories' which show the pictures and phone numbers of -----. Drugs are strictly banned and carry severe sentences if found in possession of. Korea is a very expensive country. The exchange rate is approximately 1000 wons for 1 US$. The two famous markets are Namdaemon market and Dangdaemon market. Seoul busses and subway is very clean and very cheap. Try keeping a phrase book, which has Korean characters in it. Show it to your fellow shoppers and they will guide you or bargain if possible. Don't count on the courtesy of the salespersons to help you out.

è incredibile come , una volta uscito dall'aeroporto ( sono tutti uguali, e parlo culturalmente) e calatomi nel traffico , in mezzo alla gente, alla loro vita mi sono sentito davvero lontano dall'Italia.I loro sorrisi, la loro gentilezza mi hanno spinto sempre di più verso un ignoto che mi turbava...incomprensibile...luoghi , monumenti, templi, ristoranti , aziende...che come un vaccino mi sono passate negli occhi...iniettandomi l'incompresibile sensazione d'essere davvero ...forestiero.

capitale della Corea del Sud, Seoul è una città ricca e dinamica sotto ogni punto di vista..muoversi nella città risulta molto ma molto semplice (9 linee della metropolitana e in più i bus!!!)..la città risulta essere coloratissima, ma in alcuni casi anche un pò sporca..è comunque da vedere!!

Seoul ist das perfekte Beispiel für Großstadtjungel. Die Stadt ist einfach riesig. Die Einwohner bewegen sich eher nur in ihren Vierteln, als dass sie quer durch die Stadt fahren. Ich fand es fehlte ein wenig die Familiarität einer kleineren Stadt. Alles sehr anonym und kalt. Das Essen auf den Straßen ist unglaublich fettig, in den Restaurants unglaublich scharf. Es gibt schon einige Sehenswürdigkeiten aber generell fand ich, dass Seoul kulturell nicht soviel zu bieten hat, wie andere asiatische Städte. Zum Einkaufen ist es aber hervorragend!
去了一趟，球场很干净，首尔整个都很干净，晚上光着脚跑被人误认为是日本人，丢人了一把，韩国的饭我实在是享受不了，不喜欢甜不甜算不算辣不辣的怪味道。明洞也没好好玩上··

Questà città è infinita. Come tutte le grandi metropoli è piena di inquinamento ed il cielo è grigio, la maggior parte delle persone gira con la mascherina. Ha ben 8 linee di metropolitana con indicazioni solo in koreana, diventa difficile muoversi. Per fortuna i taxi non costano molto. Negli ultimi anni stanno cercando di rendere attraente una città dominata dalla tecnologia e innovazione. Infatti hanno riaperto uno stream del fiume facendo un luogo romantico, e stanno ricostruendo tutti i palazzi e i giardini.

2時間程度のフライトでいけるソウルですが、お肉が苦手なので食べるものがあるかな？と心配だったので、今まで足が遠のいていました。実際は焼き肉だけでなく、海産物を使ったお料理も多く、おいしい！ツアーではなく個人旅行だったので、ハングルが全く分からない私たち夫婦は動きにくいかと心配だったのですが、観光客が立ち寄る場所では日本語、英語でコミュニケーションがとれます。シティツアーバスの一日券を買えば、お得にめぼしい施設を回ることが可能です。席には日本語のオーディオガイドが付いているので、説明を聞いているだけでも楽しい。好きな場所で降りて観光、また30分ごとに回ってくるバスに一日券を見せて次の場所に行けます。地下鉄も外国人観光客にわかりやすくなっていて、速く安く移動できます。震災後日本はどこに行ってもどんよりと暗く沈んだ雰囲気ですが、ソウルに行ってにぎやかで働き者の韓国の方から元気をもらったような気がします。

Aber lecker sind die direkt am Tisch gegrillten Dinge und wer gut im Schneidersitz sitzen und essen kann, wird sich hier wohl fühlen. Die Menschen sind herzlich und gerne würde ich bald wieder kommen
